content: details created by revukan fendrenim published on ravelry as a free download at https //www ravelry com/patterns/library/warframe-sawgaw-floof - post your finished projects there - hook size 3mm or small enough to crochet your chosen yarn somewhat tight enough to not let the filling peek through - pattern is of advanced difficulty - there are many parts and the attachment process requires patience and some precision as well as some level of freehanding - for the eyes i used plastic safety eyes but if you have an alternative i m not going to stop you you will also need filling and a tapestry needle - pattern uses three yarns of the same size but different colours the yarn that this pattern was made with is https //www ravelry com/yarns/library/zeeman-royal the three colours referred to in this pattern will be belly colour blue in pictured takes about 36m/15g wing colour black in pictured takes about 120m/50g with mentioned yarn and accent colour white in pictured takes about 36m/15g - the finished sawgaw takes up ~30cm horizontally ~22cm vertically and ~20cm in width - you can freely use this pattern and share the results provided you credit the pattern where you share it and do not claim it as your own do not redistribute the pattern if you have questions about your intended usage of the pattern or other questions about the pattern contact the creator at revfendrenim@gmail com terms us terminology is used ● mc magic_ring ● single_crochet single_crochet ● chain chain ● increase increase 2 scs in one stitch ● decrease decrease 1 single_crochet across two stitches ● slip_stitch slip_stitch ● abc x y repeat abc y times ● fo fasten_off this pattern is easier if at the end of each row worked in the round you slip_stitch into the first stitch of that row then ch1 up and start again from there this approach leaves a bit of a visible ridge on one side of the piece but you don t have to use stitch markers and your row start and end evenly you can leave the ridge on the inside of the pieces where it won t be visible anyway i used this approach on my pictured finished objects at the end of a row it is noted how many stitches total you should have after the row within round brackets like 12 when fastening off make sure to leave a long enough tail for sewing this will be necessary for almost every piece - only the tail piece won t need one pattern the first part of this pattern is to make all the different parts that will get attached together in the second part to get started below is a sketch of the different components of a sawgaw floof and how they will fit together not showing the belly as that is not visible on a side view all components put next to one another head floofs make 2 of these start with the wing colour r1
